cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:15

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The greater the effort made by the “owner” of information to protect it from disclosure both within and outside of the organization, the greater the likelihood that the courts will consider the information to be confidential. The party seeking to protect information must “limit the dissemination of it or at least not encourage or permit widespread publication”.[1] This principle is well established in Canadian law. For example, International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar[2] involved employees who had been provided with limited access to a specific area of the employer's plant for a limited purpose. The area was completely secured, difficult to access, and marked by signs prohibiting entry. The court, in preventing the recipients from making use of or disclosing the information in question, observed that:

A high degree of secrecy was maintained in connection with the pinmaking; it was done in a locked area to which the only access was through the office of a managerial employee and to the door of which only two keys were in existence; the presence of “No Admission” signs on the door, the masking of the glass partition to prevent observation from outside of what was going on inside, all served to reinforce the warning which the defendants had been given.[3]

Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler,[4] a decision of the English Court of Appeal, involved a former employee, Fowler, who established a business in competition with the plaintiff following his departure from employment. The plaintiff company was in the business of marketing fresh chickens from refrigerated vans that travelled particular routes. The plaintiff sought to restrain Fowler from using sales and pricing information related to the company's customers and business. The court outlined a number of factors that may assist an “owner” when seeking protection, including restriction of the circulation of information to a limited number of individuals, impressing on any recipient the confidentiality of the information through specific instructions and warnings, and the overall attitude of the employer towards the information.[5] In the circumstances, the Court of Appeal concluded that a number of factors led to the clear conclusion that the information at issue did not have the necessary degree of confidentiality, including:
The information at issue was necessarily acquired by all of the defendants in order to perform their work.
The information was generally known among employees, including those at a very junior level.
There was no evidence that the plaintiff had ever given any express instructions that the information was to be treated as confidential.
Faccenda Chicken has been cited with approval in a number of Canadian cases.[6]

Once information is disclosed to a wide enough audience, it loses its confidential character.[7] On the other hand, protection will normally be granted where information remains circulated to a small or select number of people.[8] The burden will be on the owner of information to avoid dissemination beyond that which is necessary in the circumstances. The question of when confidential status is lost will depend upon the facts of the individual case.[9]

In one case, where the control exercised over information alleged to be confidential was “sloppy”, and the plaintiffs took no action to recover the so-called confidential documents for approximately one year, the court refused to grant an interlocutory injunction.[10] However, at least one subsequent case, Tree Savers International Ltd. v. Savoy,[11] which relied upon the Coco[12] case, protected information in circumstances where the owner was somewhat careless with respect to its protection.

In Geophysical Service Inc. v. 612469 Alberta Ltd.,[13] GSI sought compensation from the Defendant CalWest for copying its seismic data that CalWest accessed from the National Energy Board's offices in 2010. In January 2010, employees of CalWest accessed and copied the 1982 Data from the National Energy Board's offices in Calgary and forwarded the microfiches that the 1982 Data was reproduced on, to its customer, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Wildlife of the Government of Quebec.[14]

The trial judge agreed that the 1982 Data was confidential in that it was information of a very technical nature that was guarded very closely, stored in locked highly secure areas, and only released under strict conditions. However, in these circumstances, the 1982 Data was not imparted to CalWest with an obligation of confidence. CalWest accessed the material from the NEB's offices, not from GSI. Further, although the President of CalWest, may have had some concern about the fact that it may be copyrighted because of a sign he saw at the NEB's offices, he did not understand that the material was “confidential”, but presumed that it was open to the public to access legally. Also, the labels on the material itself that asserted GSI's propriety, would not have been visible in the microfiche format. There was not an “unauthorised” use of the 1982 Data, since it was available for copying at the NEB offices. Accordingly, the 1982 Data accessed by CalWEst was not “confidential information”.[15]
